regularExpressionInterpreter.pattern: The '(?<StartTag>\w*?)' start tag on line (?<LineNumber>[\d{1,}\,]) position (?<Position>[\d{1,}\,]) does not match the end tag of '(?<EndTag>\w*?)'

div.p: The XML document has a major structural problem. XML documents are structured through the use of tags. All tags must have a start tag (e.g. ) and an end tag (e.g. ). The only exception are tags that are "self-closing" (e.g. ).
All tags must be closed in the inverse order to that which they're created.
As an example, the following is valid:
Whereas the following is not:
The structural issue will need to be resolved manually. Typically the error message will give both line number and position of the error.

regularExpressionInterpreter.pattern: Cannot load the schema for the namespace

div.p: One of the locations within the XML Schema-Instance 'schemaLocation' attributes could not be loaded. The error message will contain details on the exact error. Please note that if an XSD file cannot be loaded then the validation may fail and cause a large number of warnings to be reported - fixing this may resolve other reported issues.

To resolve the issue you must identify the source of the error: If the error code returned is "404" then the Uri to the XSD file is incorrect, the XSD file has not been uploaded, or the web server isn't serving the XSD file properly. If the error code returned is "500" then the XSD file is not being served properly; due to the fact that XSD files are not normally dynamically created, this is typically due to a server misconfiguration. If the error code returned is "403" then there is a permissions problem accessing the Uri.

The 'xmlns' attribute could not be found on the root node. Without this attribute, the document namespace cannot be found. Please note that if a namespace is not defined then the validation will fail and cause a large number of warnings to be reported - fixing this may resolve other reported issues.
More information on XML namespaces - including identifying the default document namespace - can be found on the references page.

regularExpressionInterpreter.pattern: Missing XML Schema-Instance 'schemaLocation' attribute on root node

div.p: The XML Schema-Instance 'schemaLocation' attribute could not be found on the root node. This attribute ties together the namespaces used within the document and the XSD documents that define their correct structure.

To resolve the issue, add in a valid XML Schema-Instance 'schemaLocation' attribute on the root node. The value of the attribute should specify an XSD document for each namespace used within the document. More information on XML namespaces can be found on the references page.

regularExpressionInterpreter.pattern: Unexpected end of file has occurred.

div.p: The XML document has a major structural problem. XML documents are structured through the use of tags. All tags must have a start tag (e.g. ) and an end tag (e.g. ). The only exception are tags that are "self-closing" (e.g. ).
All tags must be closed in the inverse order to that which they're created.
As an example, the following is valid:
Whereas the following is not:
The structural issue will need to be resolved manually. Typically the error message will give both line number and position of the error.

regularExpressionInterpreter.pattern: The value '(?<AttributeNamespace>\w*?):(?<AttributeName>\w*?)' is invalid according to its schema type '(?<SchemaType>\w*?)' - '(?<Namespace>\w*?)' is an undeclared namespace.

div.p: The value specified within an attribute contained a namespace that was not defined.
As an example, an attribute may be defined as 'xsi:type="geo:lat"'. This error would be thrown if the geo prefix has not been defined.
Add a namespace prefix definition to the root node. There is more information on XML namespaces and prefixes on the references page.
In this specific instance, this would be added as: 'xmlns:geo="http://www.w3.org/2003/01/geo/wgs84_pos"'

Please note that your feed will still fail validation if you do not reference an applicable XSD for the 'geo' namespace. Whilst there is not an official XSD, you may download and use a sample XSD stub from the references page for use with XCRI-CAP 1.1.
In this specific instance, this would be added as: 'xmlns:ukprn="http://www.ukrlp.co.uk"'

Please note that your feed will still fail validation if you do not reference an applicable XSD for the 'ukprn' namespace. Whilst there is not an official XSD, you may download and use a sample XSD stub from the references page for use with XCRI-CAP 1.1.

regularExpressionInterpreter.pattern: The element '(?<ParentName>\w*?)' in namespace '(?<ParentNamespace>[^']*?)' has invalid child element '(?<ChildName>\w*?)' in namespace '(?<ChildNamespace>[^']*?)'. List of possible elements expected: '(?<AllowedName>[^']*?)' in namespace '(?<AllowedNamespace>[^']*?)'.

div.p: An element was found in the XML file that was unexpected. Any XSD file may define the order in which 'child' elements may appear under a 'parent'. In the case of the XCRI-CAP 1.1 XSD file, the order of the child elements is specified and, as such it is required that the 'child' elements are output in this specific order.

As an example, the validator may report that "The element 'provider' in namespace 'http://xcri.org/profiles/catalog' has invalid child element 'url' in namespace 'http://xcri.org/profiles/catalog'. List of possible elements expected: 'phone, fax, email, course' in namespace 'http://xcri.org/profiles/catalog'.". This means that the <url> ('child') element was not expected in this location under the <provider> ('parent') element.
In order to resolve this issue you may need to look up the parent element within the wiki and identify the order in which the elements are expected.

regularExpressionInterpreter.pattern: The element '(?<ParentName>\w*?)' in namespace '(?<ParentNamespace>[^']*?)' has invalid child element '(?<ChildName>\w*?)' in namespace '(?<ChildNamespace>[^']*?)'. List of possible elements expected: '(?<AllowedName>[^']*?)' in namespace '(?<AllowedNamespace>[^']*?)'.

div.p: An element was found in the XML file that was unexpected. Any XSD file may define the order in which 'child' elements may appear under a 'parent'. In the case of the XCRI-CAP 1.1 XSD file, the order of the child elements is specified and, as such it is required that the 'child' elements are output in this specific order.

As an example, the validator may report that "The element 'provider' in namespace 'http://xcri.org/profiles/catalog' has invalid child element 'url' in namespace 'http://xcri.org/profiles/catalog'. List of possible elements expected: 'phone, fax, email, course' in namespace 'http://xcri.org/profiles/catalog'.". This means that the <url> ('child') element was not expected in this location under the <provider> ('parent') element.
In order to resolve this issue you may need to look up the parent element within the wiki and identify the order in which the elements are expected.

regularExpressionInterpreter.pattern: The element '(?<ParentName>\w*?)' in namespace '(?<ParentNamespace>[^']*?)' cannot contain text.

div.p: Some elements within the XML schemas are allowed to contain text (e.g. a description or title), whereas some elements are meant to contain other elements (e.g. an address should contain postcodes, etc). An element within the XML document contains text when it should contain elements.
As an example, this would be invalid:
Instead, this would be valid:
In order to resolve this issue you will need to look up the parent element within the wiki and identify the elements that are expected within the node.
An 'xsi:type' attribute was found on a node, but there was a problem identifying the type indicated.

As an example, the validator may report that there is an invalid type of "http://www.ukrlp.co.uk/:ukprn". This is typically because the "http://www.ukrlp.co.uk/" namespace has been defined but a XSD for that namespace has not been loaded.

The resolution is to ensure that the namespace is correctly defined and a valid XSD referenced within the root node's xsi:schemaLocation attribute. There is more information on defining XML namespaces and referencing XSD documents at the references page.

In this specific instance, it seems that an XSD has not been loaded for the geolocation (http://www.w3.org/2003/01/geo/wgs84_pos) namespace. Whilst there is not an official XSD, you may download and use a sample XSD stub from the references page for use with XCRI-CAP 1.1.

In this specific instance, it seems that an XSD has not been loaded for the UK Provider Reference Number (http://www.ukrlp.co.uk/) namespace. Whilst there is not an official XSD, you may download and use a sample XSD stub from the references page for use with XCRI-CAP 1.1.

regularExpressionInterpreter.pattern: Could not find schema information for the (?<Type>\w*?)

div.p: The validator could not find schema information for one or more elements within the XML document. This could be if an XML namespace has been defined, but no XSD file has been loaded for it, or if no default namespace has been defined for the document.

The resolution is to ensure that the namespace is correctly defined and a valid XSD referenced within the root node's xsi:schemaLocation attribute. There is more information on defining XML namespaces and referencing XSD documents at the references page. More information on referencing XSD files can be found on the references page.
If no default namespace ("xmlns") attribute exists, documentation on adding one can be found on the references page.
